awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining CIP: Cyberinfrastructure Expertise on High-throughput Networks for Big Science Data Transfers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project establishes the Cyberinfrastructure Network of Expertise (CNE) for teaching, training, and research on networking technologies including Science Demilitarized Zone (Science DMZ). The Science DMZ is a network specifically designed to facilitate the transfer and sharing of very large scientific data (big data) across geographically separated sites. The project serves the national interest, as it addresses the shortage of skilled research personnel with specialized skills to support networks carrying big science data among research institutions, universities, and national laboratories. This initiative also fosters skills toward the development of a national "cyber-highway" system to better facilitate the sharing of big science data, hence promoting collaboration and national competitiveness in science and engineering, aligned with NSF's mission. CNE is composed of universities, industry organizations, national and state agencies in multiple states, and a national laboratory. This broad initiative ensures a strong adoption of best cyberinfrastructure (CI) practices in sharing terabytes of data and more, thereby enabling new modes of discovery and collaboration. Additionally, the project develops advanced instructional material for Science DMZ, which is being integrated into undergraduate courses in information technology, computer science, and engineering in multiple universities. 

CNE is anchored at the University of South Carolina (USC) and has several thrusts. First, the instructional material is enriched with a large number of virtual laboratories (vLabs), designed in partnership with domain experts and the Network Development Group (NDG), a company in virtualized training. The material covers key aspects of the Science DMZ, including wide area networks, routers and switches, TCP attributes for big data transfers, and cybersecurity for friction-free environments. Second, the CNE partnership also includes Florida Atlantic University (FAU) and University of South Florida (USF), which are incorporating the vLabs and companion material into their degree programs. These enriched programs provide skills to fulfill pressing demands in both South Carolina and Florida. Third, in conjunction with local industry and Savannah River National Laboratory, CNE incorporates internships and industry-sponsored capstone projects in student training to strengthen the cooperation between academia and industry and to bolster national security related to big data transfers. Fourth, CNE organizes workshops to provide critical training and education on Science DMZs in partnership with Internet2 and state agencies, namely South Carolina Cyber (SC Cyber) and the Florida Center for Cybersecurity (FC2). Finally, by leveraging the extensive dissemination channels of all project partners, CNE plans to make vLabs and manuals available to the wider CI community for online self-paced self-training delivery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project established a network of collaborators and expertise on networking technologies supporting scientific research. It attained the following goals: 1) Enhanced the capacity for hands-on training and education for cyberinfrastructure (CI) professionals by complementing the current enterprise-based curriculum with additional material for Science Demilitarized Zones (Science DMZs), high-throughput high-latency environments for big data transfers; and 2) Established effective workforce partnerships and dissemination channels.

To attain Goal 1, the project developed more than 150 virtual laboratory (vLabs) experiments distributed among 12 libraries. Libraries cover introductory to advanced topics that are relevant to Science DMZs, high-performance networks, network programmability, and routing for research and education networks. The vLabs run on a purpose-built virtual platform for hands-on training and education. Each library focuses on a specific topic (e.g., perfSONAR, Network Tools and Protocols for Science DMZs, Inter-domain Routing with BGP, P4 Programmable Data Plane Switches, Network Management) and consists of between 10-15 vLabs that enable learners to acquire in-depth knowledge on the topic. The platform allows learners to seamlessly perform the vLabs by using a simple browser-based user interface, and to realize systems that may not be realized in other clouds (e.g., deploying equipment pods composed of physical switches). The vLabs have been incorporated into engineering and information technology programs at the University of South Carolina (USC), the University of South Florida (USF), and the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). During the four-year project, more than 100,000 hours of laboratory experiments were conducted with over 20,000 vLabs sessions.

To attain Goal 2, the project coordinated with several national and regional research and education networks (RENs), including Internet2, ESnet (CA), the Engagement and Performance Operations Center (EPOC) (IN), Western Academy Support and Training Center (WASTC) (CA), Lonestar Education And Research Network (LEARN) (TX), Southern Crossroads / Southern Light Rail (SOX / SLR) (GA), Virginia Cyber Range (VA), Great Plains Network (GPN) (MO), the New York State Education and Research Network (NYSERNET) (NY), Florida LambdaRail (FLR) (FL), and the Corporation for Education Network Initiatives in California (CENIC). These organizations build and operate national and regional networks and Science DMZs; provide services and technical support to their numerous stakeholders; and facilitate formal and informal training for CI professionals. In cooperation with the above RENs, the project organized 25 workshops and tutorials with nearly 3,000 attendees who acquired advanced skills using the vLabs libraries. Workshops and tutorials were organized as stand-alone events or co-located to conferences such as Internet2 Technology Exchange, NSF Campus Cyberinfrastructure (CC*) Annual PI Workshop, and CENIC Annual Conference. The project team also published a book and tutorial articles on peer-reviewed journals, accompanied by vLabs. Additionally, the project aligned vLabs with skills demanded by businesses and agencies. This effort permitted over 200 undergraduate students to complete 400-hour internships and/or industry-sponsored capstone projects.

Due to the successful results, the main initiatives of the project have remained active: developing new vLabs libraries, organizing tutorials and workshops in cooperation with RENs, recruiting organizations for internships and capstone projects, and conducting research on CI. Furthermore, the virtual platform has been expanded with new vLabs libraries covering other areas beyond networking, such as cybersecurity and virtualization.
